body.header: Look carefully at charts 1 and 2 and complete the reports by filling each gap with the correct tense of one of the verbs provided. Write the verb in the appropriate gap.

p.font: Chart 1 shows changes in the newspaper industry in Indonesia between 1995 and 1999. During the first four years of this period, the number of newspaper titles published more or less stable. The figure slightly in 1997, but otherwise it between 76 and 77 titles. By 1999, however, the situation dramatically. The number of titles published to over 170. A significant proportion of these new titles tabloids. In fact, by 1999 the number of tabloids from 2 to 30.

Over the same period, the overall circulation figures for Indonesian newspapers dramatically. Between 1995 and 1997 the total circulation steadily to a little over 4.7 million copies. By 1998, however, the figure to over 5 million. It then to just under 4.8 million a year later.

Chart 2; The line graph shows the dramatic increase that since the 1960s in the number of commercial satellites launched, many of which are used to broadcast television signals around the globe. In the 1960s there an average of about 15 satellite launches per year. From that time until the 1980s, the average number of satellites launched every decade. By the 1990s the number of launches , reaching an average of approximately 215 per year. It is forecast that by the end of the first decade of this century, the number of new satellites sent into orbit roughly 320 per year.

section.p: In Unit 1 and Unit 5 we looked at static charts - charts that do not show change over time. We saw that simple tenses were most appropriate for describing such charts. In this unit and in Unit 2 we have been dealing with charts and graphs that show changes over time. These are sometimes referred to as 'dynamic' charts and graphs. To describe this kind of chart you need to use a greater variety of verb tenses including past simple, past perfect and occasionally present perfect or future perfect.
